I now wish to enter the ocean to seek many precious treasures, and then return to distribute them to the people to relieve their shortages. I only pray that you will allow me to fulfill my aspirations.
When his parents heard these words, they were shocked and asked:
People in the world who enter the ocean are destitute and have no plan, recklessly abandoning their lives without any regard.
What is your purpose in wanting to engage in this?
If you wish to give alms, all the possessions in our home and the remaining treasures in the storehouse are all yours to use. Do not enter the great ocean.

Moreover, there are many great dangers in the ocean, such as water waves, whirlpools, makaras, giant fish, evil dragons, rÄká¹£asas, and mountains of water color. Such dangers are difficult to pass through.
What urgent matter do you have that you would throw yourself into such danger?
As long as we are alive, we will never agree.
You should give up your idea and not cause too much trouble.'
When MahÄsattva heard this, his wish was not fulfilled, and he was very upset, thinking to himself:
'The great matter I now wish to accomplish, if I am still attached to this body, how can it be accomplished?
' He spread his body on the ground, prostrated before his parents, and said:
'If you insist on keeping me and going against my wish, I will lie on the ground and never get up again.'
When his parents heard this, their hearts were burning with worry. They went forward with the inner officials to admonish him, saying:
'The ocean route is far away, with many dangers and difficulties. Many have gone, but few have returned.
We remember that we prayed for a son, making offerings to the gods everywhere with sincere and earnest thoughts. After twelve years, we finally got you.
Now that you have grown up, do you want to abandon us?
Thinking of abandoning this resolve, he returned to eat and drink.
From one day to two days, up to six days, he admonished and consoled in various ways;
His words were as before, and he did not change his resolve.
His parents were afraid and discussed among themselves:

'Before this, whenever our child wanted to do something, he would see it through to the end and never give up halfway. Even if he were to go to sea, we would still hope for his return. Now, if we insist on blocking him, on the seventh day, we will see his misfortune. What should we do?
We should allow him to go and worry about it later.
' Having decided, they both came to their child and held his hands, saying to him:
'We will allow you to do as you wish. Get up and return to eat.'
'MahÄdÄna, having heard this, immediately got up and went to eat.
After the meal, he got up and went outside, widely proclaiming and informing the people:
I now wish to personally enter the ocean to collect treasures. Who wishes to go?
You may come with me.
I will be the leader, and I will prepare my own provisions.
At that time, five hundred people in the country, upon hearing this order, all agreed to go.
They immediately prepared what was needed and set a date to depart.

On the appointed day, they loaded up their vehicles, took leave of their families, and set out on their way. The king, ministers, parents, princes, and countless thousands of people escorted them part of the way, each giving them wonderful treasures and provisions for their journey. They wept and parted ways.
After traveling for several days, they stopped to rest in the wilderness. They encountered a group of bandits who came to spy and steal;
the Bodhisattva took pity on them and gave them all the provisions he had brought.
They continued on and reached a city called PÄtrapuá¹­a, where there was a brÄhman named Kapila.
At that time, MahÄsattva went to his place and wanted to borrow three thousand taels of gold.

At that time, the brÄhman had a wonderful woman whose body was purple-golden in color, her hair was dark blue, she was upright and incomparably beautiful, and there was no one who could compare with her. The princes of eighty-four thousand small countries all sought her, but she did not agree to any of them.
At that time, MahÄsattva arrived at her gate and asked KÄpila:
I wish to meet you.
The woman was inside and heard the voice outside. She was delighted and startled. She said to her parents:
The one outside is my husband.
At that time, KÄpila came out to meet him and saw his appearance. He knew that he was certainly not an ordinary person. Hearing that he needed gold, he agreed to give him everything.
Moreover, he held a golden water pot in his left hand and held the woman in his right hand. He said to MahÄsattva:
'Now, this daughter of mine has an extraordinary appearance. The kings have sent messengers, each asking for her for their son;
Seeing that SÄrthavÄha is upright and similar, I request this daughter to serve you.'
MahÄdatta replied:
'I am now about to enter the ocean through difficulties. How can I know if I will be able to return safely?
Accepting the king's daughter in advance is not appropriate.'
Kapila said:
'If you return safely, I will accept her for you.'
At that time, MahÄdatta immediately agreed.
Then Kapila rejoiced and gave him 3,000 taels of gold and other necessities.

They then parted ways and went to the ocean. He ordered the merchants to repair the ship, making it seven layers, waiting for the wind to push it into the ocean. He tied it to the shore with seven large ropes, then shook the bell and announced to the merchants:

'All of you listen to the difficulties in the ocean: black winds, rÄká¹£asÄ«s, water waves, whirlpools, evil dragons, poisonous vapors, water-colored mountains, makaras, and great fish - there are many difficulties.

Those who wish to turn back can stay here;
After the ropes are cut, it will be too late to regret it.

If you can be firm-minded, disregard your body and life, part with your parents, brothers, wives and children, and encounter safety, and return with the seven treasures, your descendants for seven generations will have inexhaustible provisions.'
Having given this order, he then cut one rope, doing this every day;

after seven days, he again gave the order and cut the seventh rope. They raised the sails in the direction of the wind, and the ship sped like an arrow, and together with all the merchants, they reached the treasure island.

MahÄsattva was well-versed and knowledgeable about various treasures, their lightness and heaviness, value and worthlessness, and their good and bad appearances. He showed the merchants, saying, Treasures of this kind are not heavy but valuable, so you may take them.
Treasures of this kind are heavy but of little value, so do not take them.

He also instructed them on the proper amount of treasures to take, saying, They should be just enough to fill the boat. Too many will make the boat heavy and sink, while too few will not compensate for the hard work.
After giving these instructions, they all diligently collected the treasures and piled them on the boat. When the treasures were sufficient, they prepared to return.
At that time, MahÄsattva did not want to board the boat. All the people gathered and asked him the reason. MahÄsattva replied,
I want to go further to the Dragon King's palace to seek the wish-fulfilling jewel. I will not return until I obtain it, even if it costs me my life.
When the merchants heard this, they were distressed and helpless. They all said to him,

Now, why do you want to abandon us?'
The great giver replied:
'I will make a vow for you, to ensure that you all return to your country safely.'
When the merchants heard this, their frightened minds were put at ease.
The great giver, the guide, holding an incense burner, faced the four directions and made a vow:
'I do not begrudge the effort, crossing the ocean to seek treasures, using them to save the starving and destitute masses. I gather this merit to seek Buddhahood.
If my sincerity is to be fulfilled, let this group of merchants, the ship and its treasures, not encounter any calamity, but safely return to the country.'
After making the vow, the merchants fell at the guide's feet, weeping and lamenting, taking leave to return home.
Cutting the rope and hoisting the sail, they returned to JambudvÄ«pa, all of them peacefully escaping the great ocean.
At that time, MahÄdatta, after parting with the group, went forward into the water, which was about knee-deep, and walked for seven days;
he continued to walk forward, and the water gradually became deeper, reaching his thighs, and he walked for another seven days;

in this way, he advanced for seven days with the water reaching his waist, seven days with the water reaching his neck, and seven days constantly floating, until he reached the side of a mountain, grabbed a tree with both hands, and climbed up the mountain, spending seven days before reaching the mountain peak.
On the mountain peak, he walked horizontally for seven days, and then went down the mountain again, seven days to reach the bottom, to the side of the water.
In the water, there were golden lotus flowers everywhere, and there were poisonous snakes, their poison extremely virulent, all coiling around the roots of the lotus flowers.

The Bodhisattva, seeing this, immediately sat upright, focused his mind, and entered the samÄdhi of loving-kindness. The Great Giver then arose, stepped on the flowers, and continued on his way. After seven more days, he managed to cross the snakes.
He proceeded further and saw the rÄká¹£asas. Smelling the human scent, they all came to search for him.
The Great Giver, having seen them, focused his mind on loving-kindness. The rÄká¹£asas gave rise to a respectful mind by themselves and came to ask in gentle words:
Where are you going?
The Great Giver replied in detail:
I wish to seek the wish-fulfilling jewel.
The rÄká¹£asas rejoiced and thought to themselves:

I shall carry him over the dangerous paths.'
He then carried him over four hundred yojanas and let him down.
Then the Great Giver continued on his way and saw a silver city, bright and pure. Knowing it was a dragon city, he joyfully went there.
He saw outside the city seven layers of moats, filled with poisonous snakes, their poison fierce and repulsive to behold.

The Great Giver, the guide, thought that the poisonous snakes were all due to their previous lives of anger and harm, and thus received such repulsive forms. He thought of compassion and pity, as if seeing his own children, and with his mind full of kindness, the snake poison was all removed.
He then rose up and walked to the dragon city.
He saw two dragons coiling around the city, their heads crossing the threshold of the gate, looking up at the Great Bestower with wide eyes.
The Great Bestower then entered the mind of loving-kindness again, the dragon's poison was immediately removed, and it lowered its head and did not look up.
The Great Bestower then stepped forward and passed over it.
In the city, a dragon sitting in a seven-jeweled hall saw the Bodhisattva from afar, was startled and thought:
Outside my city, in the seven moats, there are poisonous snakes, other dragons, and yakshas, none of whom dare to cross over.
Who is this person who can come here?
He then went forward to welcome and ask questions, made respectful prostrations, invited him to sit on a seven-jeweled seat, and made offerings with various delicious foods.

At that time, there was a dragon king in the city, sitting in a hall of the seven treasures. Seeing the Bodhisattva from afar, he was startled and thought to himself:

The Bodhisattva agreed, saying:

The dragon immediately replied:

The Bodhisattva thought to himself:

The dragons, young and old, saw him off outside the gate, each feeling sad and regretful.

At that time, there was also a dragon king in the city, sitting in a jeweled palace. Seeing the Bodhisattva from afar, he was startled and thought to himself:

His mind was extremely surprised, and he immediately went down to welcome and ask questions, paying respect and offering a seat in the palace, offering a seven-jeweled bed, and letting him sit on it. I have heard that the Dragon King of the Ocean has a wish-fulfilling jewel, so I have traveled through the vast and dangerous [journey] just hoping to obtain this.
The Dragon King replied:

The dragon king was delighted and set up a hundred flavors of the finest delicacies every day. The great being's vast vows, compassionate mind, and far-reaching salvation, with pity for the multitude of beings, not shunning hard work, will surely be able to attain Buddhahood and deliver those in distress. I wish to be his attendant and disciple who upholds the teachings.
The Bodhisattva accepted this.
He also asked again:
'What is the power of the pearl you are giving?'
The dragon king replied:

The Bodhisattva was delighted and thought to himself:
'The land of Jambudvipa is seven thousand yojanas. The virtue of this pearl matches my expectations.'
He had obtained three pearls in total, which he tied to the corner of his robe. He then got up and left the city.
The dragons, young and old, saw him out of the city. Each of them was filled with sadness and longing, and they eventually parted ways.
The Bodhisattva reached the front and held the pearl, making a wish:

Having passed through the sea's dangers, he took a short nap to rest. At that time, in the ocean, some dragons discussed among themselves:

Having made up his mind, he went to the shore and found a turtle shell. He held it in both hands and was about to drain the ocean. The sea god knew his intention and came to ask him:

'The ocean is deep and vast, 3,360,000 li wide. Even if all the people of the world were to come together and try to drain it, they would not be able to make it decrease, let alone you alone, who wishes to accomplish this.'
The Bodhisattva replied:
'If a person is sincere and wishes to accomplish something, nothing will not be accomplished.

The Bodhisattva took out the vessel, and all the devas, with their heavenly garments, covered the water together. When the Bodhisattva took out the vessel, the devas lifted up the garments and threw them elsewhere. Stirring the ocean once, it decreased by forty li;

I, as a human, understand the Dharma and transformation, so I have come to seek treasures, first to fulfill their needs, and later to exhort them with the ten wholesome deeds.'
When the dragon heard these words, he took out the pearl and returned it.
At that time, the sea deity, seeing his diligence and strength, made a vow, saying:
'Since you are so diligent and do not rest, you will surely attain Buddhahood. I vow to become your diligent disciple.'
The Bodhisattva obtained the pearl and flew away again.
When he arrived, he first asked the merchant companions who had entered the ocean, and then descended to the ground.

The Bodhisattva took out the jewel and gave it to his parents. The parents held it in their hands and said to themselves:

The Bodhisattva took the jewel, pointed it at his parents' eyes, and their eyes suddenly became clear and bright, like the wind clearing away clouds. Having regained their sight, they were overjoyed and marveled at the virtue of the jewel, exclaiming:

'The people of JambudvÄ«pa are poor and suffering. I wish to provide for them and relieve their lack. If this is truly the candramani jewel, it will then rain down all that is needed in sequence.'
After making the vow, dark clouds appeared in the four directions. A wind immediately arose, blowing away all the impurities, filth, and rubbish.

Next, a fine rain fell to cover the dust, followed by a rain of food and drink, a hundred flavors of the finest delicacies, followed by a rain of the five grains, followed by a rain of clothing, followed by a rain of the seven treasures and various rare treasures, filling the entire JambudvÄ«pa with precious treasures.
